Class VirtualKeyboard

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.tasmod.virtual.VirtualKeyboard

  • public final class VirtualKeyboard
extends java.lang.Object
    This is an interface of the Keyboard Class. This File records or manipulates these Calls

    • Field Detail

      • keyEventsForTick

        public static final java.util.Queue<VirtualKeyboard.VirtualKeyEvent> keyEventsForTick
        General Idea: LWJGL uses Events, these Events contain a bit of Information VirtualKeyboard.VirtualKeyEvent. You go trough them by running next() and then you access their Information using getEvent****. So every time next() is called, a new VirtualKeyEvent is being created, that is slowly being filled with data, by Minecraft Code that is accessing them. So if the MC Code asks for the Event Key, then our Code puts that Information into the VirtualKeyEvent. Replaying works the same, but instead of listening, it hacks the LWJGL Keyboard like a Man In The Middle

      • isKeyDown

        public static boolean isKeyDown(int i)
        isKeyDown does not use the Packets, instead it looks through all passed Packets (aka. see if the button is actually down on the Keyboard) Update: ._. This is frame based and messes up Mouse Inputs entirely. Solution: Yeet this, and do a lazy play in next() Problem with that is, that officially left and right clicking in all Slot Menus (Singleplayer, Stats, Texture Pack, etc) is working a bit less. public final static boolean isKeyDown(final int i) { if (!hack) { final boolean val = Keyboard.isKeyDown(i); if (listen) { TASmod.keyboardTick(new VirtualKeyEvent(i, i, val)); } return val; } for (final VirtualKeyEvent virtualKeyEvent : keyEventsForTick) if (virtualKeyEvent.key == i && virtualKeyEvent.state == true) return true; return false; }
